DOC.brief_summary: We aim to assess, if placebo compared to preoperative administration of midazolam in elderly patients is equal in regard to the global postoperative patient satisfaction
DOC.brief_title: Impact of Preoperative Midazolam on Outcome of Elderly Patients
DOC.detailed_description: Generalised premedication with benzodiazepines in all surgical patients has become questionable, regarding the risk-benefit assessment and the lack of evidence for this practice. Particularly, in elderly patients (≥65 years), a higher risk for adverse events is described. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of the following two study groups. Preoperatively, group 1 will receive midazolam and group 2 will receive placebo. Anaesthesia will be performed according to the clinical routine. All possible side effects are described in the SmPC for midazolam. For the placebo-group, we do not expect any harm, as in the case of strong preoperative anxiety or agitation, additional midazolam application may occur on behalf of the attending anaesthesist at any time. The sample size was calculated based on detecting a minimum of 5 unit difference in the primary outcome variable overall patient satisfaction measured with the EVAN-G. Setting a type 1 error of 0.05, a power of 0.8 and assuming the standard deviation of EVAN-G to be 14 units, 248 patients per group are needed to detect a 5 unit difference. Considering a drop-out of 10% and a screening failure of 10%, we decided to include 614 patients in total. The hypothesis of the study is that global patient satisfaction after surgery in elderly patients is similar after preoperative placebo application compared to midazolam application.
DOC.criteria: 1. Written informed consent prior to study participation 2. 6580 years, both genders 3. Elective surgery 4. Expected surgery duration ≥ 30 minutes 5. Planned general or combined regional and general anaesthesia 6. Planned extubation at the end of surgery 7. Only legally competent patients 1. > 80 years 2. Alcohol and drugs abuse 3. Chronic benzodiazepine treatment 4. Intracranial surgery 5. Local and stand by anaesthesia or solely regional anaesthesia 6. Monitored anaesthesia care 7. Cardiac surgery 8. Ambulatory surgery 9. Repeated surgery 10. Contraindications for benzodiazepine application (e.g. sleep apnoea syndrome, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, allergy) 11. Expected benzodiazepine requirement after surgery 12. Patients who explicitly request anxiolytic premedication 13. Patients with severe neurological or psychiatric disorders 14. Refusal of study participation by the patient 15. Concurrent participation in interventional clinical studies within the last 30 days 16. Nonfluency in German language 17. Expected continuous mandatory ventilation after surgery
